title: Chicken Shawarma Bowls
description: Flavorful Middle Eastern-inspired chicken bowls with aromatic spices, fresh vegetables, and wholesome grains. Perfect for meal prep or a healthy weeknight dinner.
ingredients: 2 cups cooked brown rice or quinoa
1.5 tsp garlic powder or 3 garlic cloves, minced
instructions: Mix marinade ingredients in a bowl or Ziploc bag.
Add chicken thighs and coat well with the marinade.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes, ideally 4-8 hours for best flavor.
Grill or pan-sear chicken until fully cooked (internal temp 165°F), then slice into strips.
Assemble bowls with rice/quinoa as the base, then top with sliced chicken, diced cucumber, cherry tomatoes, and chopped parsley.
Add a dollop of hummus and serve with warm pita or naan bread.
Optional: drizzle with tzatziki or lemon juice.
notes: For meal prep, store components separately and assemble when ready to eat. Chicken can be marinated up to 24 hours ahead. This recipe is naturally gluten-free when served with rice/quinoa instead of pita.

title: Grilled Chicken Tenders with Avocado-Lime Yogurt Sauce
description: Perfectly seasoned grilled chicken tenders served with a creamy, tangy avocado-lime yogurt sauce. Paired with quinoa and steamed broccoli for a complete, healthy meal.
ingredients: 1 tsp garlic powder or 2 garlic cloves, minced
instructions: Preheat grill to 375°F.
Season chicken tenders with garlic powder, salt, and pepper on both sides.
Grill for 12-15 minutes, flipping once halfway through, until internal temp reaches 165°F.
While chicken cooks, blend avocado, Greek yogurt, lime juice, minced garlic, and salt until smooth and creamy.
Steam broccoli florets until fork-tender (about 5-7 minutes).
Serve grilled chicken tenders over quinoa with steamed broccoli, drizzled or dipped in the avocado-lime sauce.
notes: The avocado sauce is best made fresh but can be stored in the fridge for up to 2 days with plastic wrap pressed directly onto the surface to prevent browning. This works great on any grill or even in a grill pan indoors.

title: Homemade Taco Seasoning
description: A flavorful, customizable taco seasoning blend that's perfect for 2 pounds of ground meat. Skip the store-bought packets and make your own with simple pantry spices.
instructions: Combine all dry ingredients (chili powder, garlic powder, onion powder, oregano, paprika, cumin, and salt) in a small bowl.
Mix well until evenly combined.
Brown 2 pounds of ground meat (beef, turkey, or chicken) in a large skillet.
Add the spice mixture to the cooked meat and stir to coat evenly.
Add approximately 15 shakes of Cholula hot sauce (or to taste).
Cook for 2-3 minutes more, stirring frequently, until fragrant and well combined.
notes: This seasoning blend can be made ahead and stored in an airtight container for up to 6 months. Adjust the Cholula to your heat preference - start with less and add more as needed. Works great with ground beef, turkey, chicken, or even plant-based meat alternatives.

title: Smoked Pulled Pork
description: Tender, flavorful pulled pork with a perfect bark and smoky flavor. Low and slow cooking method with a delicious dry rub that creates an amazing crust.
instructions: Make the dry rub by combining brown sugar, paprika, salt, black pepper, cayenne, and mustard powder in a bowl.
Trim the pork butt with a sharp knife, removing any thick or excess fat.
Coat the pork butt all over with yellow mustard (helps spices adhere during cooking).
Sprinkle the pork butt liberally with the dry rub, covering all surfaces.
Let sit at room temperature for 15-30 minutes, or cover and refrigerate overnight for best results.
Preheat smoker to 275°F.
Insert a leave-in thermometer into the pork butt, aiming for the center and avoiding any bone.
Place pork butt directly on grill grate, fat side down.
Smoke until very dark mahogany color and internal temp reaches 165-175°F.
Transfer to a disposable aluminum pan. Sprinkle 1/2 cup brown sugar over the top, add butter, and pour in some apple juice.
Cover pan tightly with foil and continue smoking until internal temp reaches 204°F.
Remove from smoker, let rest for 30 minutes, then shred with forks or meat claws.
notes: The mustard won't affect the taste but helps the rub stick. Don't rush the process - low and slow is key for tender pulled pork. Internal temp of 204°F ensures the collagen breaks down properly for easy shredding.
